subject: Re: [junit] using JUnit with derived classes
msgSnippet: ... I see. If I can find an analog, there s no need for something like JUnit-addons in NUnit, because NUnit is already quite flexible. Close?  ... This
messageBody:
Curt Sampson wrote:

> On Mon, 7 Jun 2004, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > Curt Sampson wrote:
> >
> > > I think [things like declaring a test without extending TestCase are]
> > > valuable because [they give] you a lot more leway to play with
> > > the design of your testing framework within a particular application. I
> > > know that I often feel that certain refactoring directions I'd like to
> > > try are closed to me because of the fairly strict structure of the
> JUnit
> > > testing framework.
> >
> > Do you have a specific example? Given that the structure (hierarchy) of
> > test classes does not need to reflect the structure of production
> > classes, what kinds of refactorings are difficult in JUnit but easy in
> > NUnit? This is the kind of thing I need to explore, because my JUnit
> > preconceptions hold me back when thinking in NUnit. You could jump-start
> > me. :)
>
> Oh, it's often more to do with changing the testing framework itself.
> I've found that in Java I'm often stymied because someone has not
> declared an interface for something I wish he had, and so I can't
> replace his object with my own when I want to do something he's not
> considered. With languages such as SmallTalk and Ruby, this tends to be
> less of a problem because I so long as I supply an object that answers
> the necessary messages, it will work.

I see. If I can find an analog, there's no need for something like
JUnit-addons in NUnit, because NUnit is already quite flexible. Close?

<snip />
> Anyway, I've appended a little example I was playing with this morning
> where I ended up making a test suite that was just a hash of inputs
> and expected results, something you'd typically have to build up a
> parameterized test case for. The key code ends up being, instead, just:
>
>
> fibtest_hash = { 0 => 0, 1 => 1, 2 => 1, 3 => 2, 4 => 3, 5 => 5, 6
> => 8 }
>
> def fibtest_hash.calculate_result(input)
> Fib.new.fib(input)
> end
>
> fibtest_hash.extend(TestEachInputExpectedPair)
>
> Test::Unit::UI::Console::TestRunner.run(fibtest_hash)

This is the first time I've seen a singleton method, and understood what
it's for. (I had an Aha! experience very recently about the power of
such beasts.)

<pause />

I just read the relevant section in Programming Ruby about extending
objects. Very neat. I obviously need to do more Ruby programming.

> Of course, that object doesn't have to be a Hash. It might be, for
> example, a database query that pulls data from test runs against an
> oracle, or even the oracle itself:
>
> suite = SQLQuery.new("SELECT input, result FROM old_test_run")
>
> def suite.calculate_result(input)
> ...
> end
>
> suite.extend(TestEachInputExpectedPair)
>
> Test::Unit::UI::Console::TestRunner.run(suite)
>
> Unfortunately, I'm out of time today to think about this further....

Please do, and write about it. I'm going to read the code you pasted
more carefully and try to let it sink in. Neat stuff.

Thanks.
